ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In-depth overview of statistical analysis procedures for linguistic data; tidyverse, fixed- and mixed-effects models, statistical tests, non-linear regression models (logistic, poisson, etc.). Also some introduction to linguistics.
Mostly a solid foundation in R, with some added little bits of linguistics, though that is certainly not the focus of the course
A survey of concepts in statistics and linguistics. Introductory R.

Learned some basic linguistic terms and phenomena, but most of the course was focused on teaching "R" Language Programming specifically for use in linguistics and to be applied for the social sciences.
Ways to analyze language using quantitative methods

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Lots of ground covered, very in-depth examples of statistical tests that were well-written and structured for student replication

Weaknesses: 
TLDR -- more linguistics background needed for non-linguistics people, more stats background needed for non-stats people
I feel like the linguistics-related content was very difficult to understand at times, and that I personally might have benefitted from some prior knowledge of these topics in class. In a similar vein, I came from an S&DS background so I was more familiar with the coding, but for many of my classmates this was their first exposure to coding and R, so it was harder for them to succeed in the course.
The course is very good at introducing the basics of R, and framing it in linguistic contexts. It doesn't go into too much detail on either, but that's fine.

The course did teach "R" programming in an approachable way to inexperienced students, and learning it and statistics more generally using real-world applications was particularly useful and helped me understand a lot better. However, the course is advertised as open to anyone regardless of linguistics knowledge, and it was my experience that it is best suited to those with some basic knowledge of linguistics and terms. To best succeed in the class, you need either robust knowledge of statistics or linguistics, as it is unfeasible to try to learn both in order to understand the class. It is also very fast-paced and cumulative.
The course was very interesting and insightful

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you have the background. You'll learn some really useful applications of data analysis tools, but the content can be overwhelming at times and there aren't many extra resources given for students who need them.

Yes, I would recommend this course. Not a heavy lift in terms of both concepts and workload. Less linguistics than I had hoped. As someone without a background in statistics, I didnt feel like I got an in-depth understanding of any particular statistical method, instead it was more of a crash course on implementing statistical methods in R. Slides are somewhat uninformative, I think to encourage class attendance, but it made revisiting material somewhat frustrating. Psets are fair, and would probably be very easy to anyone with a stats/R background. Both Prof Ko and the TF Sammy were very approachable and helpful.
Yes! This is a great and relatively chill course for getting used to R and statistics if you're interested in linguistics. It's not an in-depth linguistics course though, so bear that in mind.

I would recommend this course to someone interested in linguistics and data analysis. While the course content is taught almost exclusively in R, someone will enjoy the class significantly more if they have an interest in linguistics and its applications in research.
I would only recommend this course to a student that has either linguistics or statistical knowledge, but not to a student with little to no experience in both.
Yes, you learn a lot about both stats and linguistics
